data.title: Famed producer, rock icon suffers fatal heart attack at 61
data.meta_description: A famous producer who worked with bands such as Nirvana has died from a heart attak.
data.text:
Steve Albini, a famous producer, musician, and an icon amongst the rock community as well as others, has passed away.

The 61-year-old — who worked with acts such as Nirvana and Pixies — was confirmed to have succumbed to a heart attack by staff at his recording studio.

Entertainment News

Country music legend’s daughter arrested in Georgia

Country music singer says doctors said he had no chance to survive medical emergency

Popular ‘90s punk rocker dead at 51

What’s killing you? Find out the CDC’s answers to that question

Hip-hop, R&B star says low ticket sales caused last-minute tour cancelation

Pitchfork reports how Albini was long considered an icon in the music industry. Not only was the California-born aficionado of sound the frontman of groups such as Rapeman, Shellac and Big Black, but was widely acclaimed for his work on classic albums such as “In Utero.”

According to The Guardian, Albini became immersed in the Chicago music scene while studying at the Medill School of Journalism, taking to punk in particular. He went on to found his own studio, Electrical Audio, and continuously took on production jobs “always for a flat fee, refusing royalty payments in a show of solidarity with his artists,” reads The Guardian report.

The same Guardian article notes that Albini had a new album coming out to be released on May 17.

“Nobody made noise sound so good,” reads one X post. “RIP Steve Albini.”

“I remember him from the Foo Fighters doc ‘Sonic Highways,’” reads another. “He never took a percentage cut of the sales on the albums he produced. He felt that was wrong. Noble thought.”
